messages: 082b9bc1657b43db3a0e0b1b0066d690 (05:46): Has anyone heard about any kind of management system for vim plugins/scripts?
082b9bc1657b43db3a0e0b1b0066d690 (05:47): I'm thinking along the lines of CPAN for perl.
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (05:47): yeah, except instead of CPAN, it's called elinks or firefox or epiphany
082b9bc1657b43db3a0e0b1b0066d690 (05:47): I've started looking at the Vimball script and GetLatestVimScripts plugin.
082b9bc1657b43db3a0e0b1b0066d690 (05:49): Well, downloading them is easy enough, but sometimes I don't want to track down the versions.
082b9bc1657b43db3a0e0b1b0066d690 (05:49): and some plugins are starting to need other plugins.
082b9bc1657b43db3a0e0b1b0066d690 (05:49): Occasionally one plugin will need slightly different installation procedures, rather than just untarring/unzipping.
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (05:50): i made a python script to compare versions - used BeautifulSoup and was like 20 lines or so...
082b9bc1657b43db3a0e0b1b0066d690 (05:50): Did it pull in any dependencies?
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (05:50): no... how would it do that... it checked versions
082b9bc1657b43db3a0e0b1b0066d690 (05:50): Have you seen the GetLatestVimScripts plugin?
082b9bc1657b43db3a0e0b1b0066d690 (05:51): http://vim.sourceforge.net/scripts/script.php?script_id=642
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (05:51): if [ $current_version -gt $(./vimscript-version taglist) ]; then blah; fi
082b9bc1657b43db3a0e0b1b0066d690 (05:53): I've gotten spoiled by package management systems like Debian's apt, or Gentoo's emerge.
082b9bc1657b43db3a0e0b1b0066d690 (05:53): And those systems are slow to adopt vim plugins.
082b9bc1657b43db3a0e0b1b0066d690 (05:54): And even if people do write ebuilds and debs you'll still have users wanting a different setup for themselves.
082b9bc1657b43db3a0e0b1b0066d690 (05:55): I just thought Vimball and GetLatestVimScripts might be part of a larger initiative.
082b9bc1657b43db3a0e0b1b0066d690 (05:55): I also thought about Makefiles for doing some of this and then I found: http://www.a-a-p.org/
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (06:03): if anyone is interested... http://www.jukie.net/~bart/scripts/tmp/vimdiff-over-unapplied-patch
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (06:03): use case: you have a patch that you only want to apply, but you don't want to apply all of it
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (06:03): example: you went too long without commiting and you don't want to commit everything
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (06:03): it runs vimdiff over each of the files modified by the patch
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (06:04): interesting
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (06:04): oh, it's actually git aware
d711e4c8dbc8ccb10d953ab45ad18a36 (06:04): I would make the name more intuitive though... something like "incremental vimdiff" or some such name
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (06:04): but you can fix that if you don't have git
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (06:05): I put vimdiff first, otherwise I would never remember the name :)
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (06:07): hmm, git-cat is required... http://www.jukie.net/~bart/scripts/tmp/git-cat
fdd2857f7e10657ff26e8adae48cfb9c (06:24): You guys have seen Yzis.org yet? pretty cool
fdd2857f7e10657ff26e8adae48cfb9c (06:25): an editor inspired by vim split into an editing component with frontends for different things like IDE's, browser textboxes, etc
fdd2857f7e10657ff26e8adae48cfb9c (06:25): s/with/and/
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (06:31): Industrial: that's pretty neat.
89c1b59bee0d5db8d28cdefc2f88cd3e (06:49): is there a way to change the current working directory in vim, so that :e will look in a different place?
43e438148dc81c8a17aa7f85deba4057 (06:51): LunarCrisis: :cd?
89c1b59bee0d5db8d28cdefc2f88cd3e (06:51): ah, thanks, I was trying :!cd =)
43e438148dc81c8a17aa7f85deba4057 (06:51): LunarCrisis: works for me...
89c1b59bee0d5db8d28cdefc2f88cd3e (06:51): that works, yay
5a39c7d82b14449a0e64d7232d073877 (07:05): hello, how do I map ctrl+n to omnifunc?
5a39c7d82b14449a0e64d7232d073877 (07:08): what is the syntax for describing keypress and modifiers? what help page can I read about it?
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:08): is ctr-x ctr-o what you want to do?
5a39c7d82b14449a0e64d7232d073877 (07:19): do I need to do something for it to load omnifuncs? it just says that ft-c-omni is not found.
cd35faceccd738f21e97eb115ec61fe5 (07:28): hia, 'ft' locate t on the current line, is there the same command for partial word such as "locate '<tr>' on current line" ?

d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:30): hello, currently on vim 6.4 with ubuntu 6.06 (dapper) wondering if someone could point me to some decent ubuntu specific compile guide or 3rd party (FUNCTIONAL) binaries for (K)Ubuntu Dapper.
ded01cf47cdca62f9adcfd25cb1b3127 (07:31): why do you need ubuntu specific compile guides?
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:32): because distro specific guides make me happy.
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:32): anything that works would be fine though :)
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:32): getting sick of dealing with debian package maintainers screwing up stable and backported vim packages.
ded01cf47cdca62f9adcfd25cb1b3127 (07:33): then stop using debian vim packages
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:33): ciaranm: exactly why i'm here :)
ded01cf47cdca62f9adcfd25cb1b3127 (07:33): and hit jamessan with a stick
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:34): :P
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:34): nah he's a cool guy.
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:35): unix_infidel: http://www.jukie.net/~bart/blog/vim7-from-source
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:36): bartman: this will take care of vim-gnome/gtk/per/python as well?
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:36): or is this only specific to the vim package, not runtime or common?
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:37): I think this is the vim-full package
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:37): hmmm. i'm going to need all of those :0
43e438148dc81c8a17aa7f85deba4057 (07:37): unix_infidel: it is complete, (--with-x, etc...)
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:38): opitzs: you are referring to that URL pasted above, yes?
43e438148dc81c8a17aa7f85deba4057 (07:38): unix_infidel: yes
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:38): ahh, it looks like everything is there as per the flags.
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:39): unix_infidel: it seems to have it all
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:39): opitzs: but shouldnt i do make install as root, that guide has $make install.
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:39): unix_infidel: yeah, let me change that
43e438148dc81c8a17aa7f85deba4057 (07:39): unix_infidel: yes, as root
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:40): bartman: you trying to break me?
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:40): ok
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:41): as long as we are on the same page
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:41): unix_infidel: you may want to change -march=pentium-m -mtune=pentium-m --with-compiledby="<email/>" and --program-suffix=7
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:42): the -m* are for gcc to optimize for my laptop cpu... your milage may vary
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:42): bartman: this is laptop as well.
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:42): and yes, i'm being very careful with this tutorial, but thanks.
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:42): then it's probably pentium-m, right?
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:42): unix_infidel: good
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:46): bartman: i should apt-get remove --purge vim first correct?
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:47): (Kubuntu 6.06)
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:48): I have both installed
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:48): but you can remove the ubuntu one
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:49): bartman: ahh, ok, i think i'll just setup an alias for the default prefix path you speced
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:49): I keep the old one just in case
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:50): heh, going to make sure to not run that last line for fix install then :)

d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:53): bloody hell is sf.net down AGAIN!
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:54): bartman: can you checkout with that command you have in blog?
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:56): $ cvs -z3 -d:pserver:<email/>:/cvsroot/vim checkout vim7
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:56): cvs [checkout aborted]: connect to cvs.sf.net(66.35.250.207):2401 failed: No route to host
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (07:56): same error
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (07:57): try svn co https://svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/vim/vim7
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (08:00): svn is subversion
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (08:00): a crappy replacement for cvs
4c002476425f2c87dbc7d5383704d9d7 (08:00): apt-get install subversion
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (08:02): unix_infidel: what's wrong with the debian packages?
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (08:02): jamessan: nothing. i was just complaining.
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (08:02): jamessan: i was using some backports that were being funky.
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (08:02): 6.4 works fine.
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (08:02): ah, I dunno what people do with the backports
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (08:03): I just maintain the stuff for unstable
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (08:03): you should put out your own backports.
d50e4c9abc8596e9cefa6f40082c8bee (08:03): but i'm sure you're a busy guy to begin with.
